Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Mechanisms of thermal ontogenetic plasticity and adaptation in native and invasive fishes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid changes in environmental conditions due to global climate change are already having profound effects around the world, and are expected to become more common in the future. Understanding the roles of tolerance, plasticity and adaptation to high temperatures is paramount to forecasting organisms? responses to climate change and making informed conservation management decisions. Our project combines ecological, physiological and genomic approaches to enhance understanding of thermal tolerance mechanisms and developmental plasticity in two sympatric fishes, the endangered endemic delta smelt (Hypomensus transpacificus), and the invasive inland silverside (Menidia beryllina). Using this approach, we will compare genes and physiological pathways used to cope with thermal challenges for these species, offering insight into which fishes will be ?winners? or ?losers? in the future, warmer world.

Most fishes are ectotherms, and global climate change is predicted to have dramatic impacts on their biodiversity and distributions. Our work will greatly enrich the understanding of the mechanisms of thermal tolerance in fish adapted to variable temperature environments, and the ability of native and invasive species with sympatric distributions to cope with climate change. Thus, this research will significant contribute to both the fundamental understanding of evolutionary ecological questions as well as issues relevant to conservation management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Global climate change is already affecting many species and ecosystems around the world. Temperature plays a fundamental role in determining organisms’ where organisms can live and how well they perform. Different species are physiologically adapted to survive and perform their best in different thermal environments. Some species are able to perform well across a broad range of temperatures by quickly adjusting their physiology, while others cannot and consequently suffer negative impacts or death. Therefore, to understand how climage change will impact species and ecosystems, it is important to study the genetic and physiological mechanisms that underly different species' abilities to tolerate and survive under different temperatures. It is particularly important to examine how these animals cope with temperature stress to understand how increasing temperatures may sublethally impact these species. 

Temperature is particularly important for fishes because their body temperatures often conform quickly to environmental temperatures. In our study, we conducted experiments with a sensitive, California native fish (delta smelt) and an invasive fish (inland silverside) to compare their physiological and genetic responses to different temperatures. We exposed both species to similar temperature challenges, and measured their tolerance, metabolic rate, and behavior. We also sampled their gill tissue to measure differences in gene expression and functional gene sequences.

We found that the invasive fish was able to tolerate and exhibit normal behavior at much higher temperatures relative to the native fish, which could assist the invasive fish in outcompeting the native fish in coming, warming decades. We are currently analyzing transcriptomic data, which will inform us about how differences in their abilities to up or downregulate certain genes in the face of temperature stress may be important to their abilities to cope with increasing temperatures. These data will also help us identify the sublethal thresholds at which each species begins to experience thermal stress, which may have negative impacts on their survival or reproduction (i.e., fitness). Our findings and data will be made publically available upon completion of these analyses. By comparing the roles of genomic and physiological mechanisms in determining temperature tolerance and performance across different types of species, we will be better able to project impacts of climate change on these organisms.
